p: The study site was a 20 km × 30 km area in the southern part of Japan’s northern Alps (36.25–36.5°N, 137.5–137.7°E), of which the highest peak is 3190 m (Fig. 1). The study area supports approximately one-third of the current L. muta japonica populations, and so represents a major component of L. muta japonica habitats. The area has deep snow in winter, due to the influence of continental polar air from Siberia and moisture from the warm currents of the Sea of Japan. The alpine vegetation, which occurs above the forest limit at approximately 2200 m above sea level, consists of Japanese stone pine ( P. pumila) scrub, snowbed grasslands (including Phyllodoce aleutica, Sieversia pentapetala, Fritillaria camschatcensis, and Primula cuneifolia var. hakusanensis), and alpine fellfields (alpine heathland and wind-exposed grassland) dominated by dwarf shrubs (including Arcterica nana, Empetrum nigrum var. japonicum, Vaccinium uliginosum, and Poaceae grasses).
